contextId.information: It is implied that the men of Simeon attacked with the men of Judah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This implies that Caleb did give her the field when she asked him for it in verse 14. In verse 15, she is now asking for springs of water in addition to that field. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: give her a field ... Since you have given me the land

contextId.information: Caleb gave Achsah in marriage to Othniel, so she lived with Othniel in the city that he had captured in the Negev. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "Since you have given me in marriage to live in the Negev" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Since you have given me the land of the Negev

contextId.information: This is another name for the city of Jericho. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

After the Israelites destroyed Zephath, they changed its name to "Hormah." The name "Hormah" means "complete destruction." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
contextId.quote: The name of the city was called Hormah

contextId.information: This statement can be made clearer. AT: "to the place Yahweh gave them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "On the day the Israelites defeated the army of King Jabin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Because of the heavy rain the river flooded quickly causing the chariots to be stuck in the mud and drowning many soldiers. AT: "The Kishon River flooded and swept away Sisera's soldiers"   (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The Kishon River swept them away

contextId.information: Apparently Yahweh spoke to Gideon from heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "gathered together as an army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "this will be a sign from you, and then I will know that you will" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: then I will know that you will

contextId.information: You can make explicit where he will go. AT: "let him return to his home" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The words "we fight" are implied. AT: "We fight for Yahweh and for Gideon!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The places were given these names after the Israelites killed Oreb and Zeeb there. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: at the rock of Oreb ... at the winepress of Zeeb

contextId.information: It can be stated explicitly what Gideon asked the young man. AT: "he asked him to identify all the names of the leaders in the town" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This implies that they want Gideon's descendants to rule over them after he dies. AT: "you and your descendants after you die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: you, your son, and your grandson

contextId.information: They did this to squeeze out the grape juice to make wine with it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"spread salt over the land." Spreading salt over land keeps anything from growing there. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit the implicit meaning of this statement. AT: "foreign gods whose images they possessed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The word "that" refers to what Jephthah said about about them being in trouble. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "We are turning to you now because we are in trouble" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: That is why we are turning to you now

contextId.information: Here the word "he" refers to the messenger who was speaking to the king. This may be written with the word "they" as in the UDB, referring to the group of messengers. AT: "Jephthah told the messengers to say" or "they said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The reason that Israel sent messengers to the king of Moab can be made explicit. AT: "They also send messengers to the king of Moab with the same request" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: They also sent messengers to the king of Moab

contextId.information: The king of Moab refused Israel's request to pass through Moab. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear.  AT: "but he also refused and would not let them pass through the land of Moab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Sihon did not trust the people of Israel to pass through his land peacefully. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "But Sihon did not trust the people of Israel to pass through his territory peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: But Sihon did not trust Israel to pass through his territory

contextId.information: Jephthah passed through these places enlisting men for his army to go to war with the people of Ammon. The full meaning of this can be made clear. AT: "he gathered men for his army as he passed through Gilead and Manasseh ... from Mizpah of Gilead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: he passed through Gilead and Manasseh ... from Mizpah of Gilead

contextId.information: Yahweh has taken vengence for him by defeating his enemies. The meaning of this can be made explicit. AT: "has taken vengeance for you against your enemies, the Ammonites, by defeating them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: has taken vengeance for you against your enemies, the Ammonites

contextId.information: This means that they fought against the Ammonites as they passed through Ammon. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "fought against the people of Ammon as we passed through their region" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: passed through against the people of Ammon

contextId.information: This means that he will be devoted to God as a Nazirite. AT: "a Nazirite devoted to God" or "devoted to God as a Nazirite" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means that the man was sent by God. This can be made explicit. AT: "A man that God sent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This means that he will be devoted to God as a Nazirite. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:13:03|3:5]]. AT: "a Nazirite devoted to God" or "devoted to God as a Nazirite" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit the implicit meaning of the author's words. AT: "came to Manoah's wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit the implicit meaning of Manoah's statement. AT: "cook a young goat for you to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: prepare a young goat for you

contextId.information: It may be helpful to explain more explicitly why they should not ask his name. AT: "It is too wonderful for you to understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This law requires a grain offering to be offered when a burnt offering is made. AT: "with the grain offering required with it" or "with the grain offering to accompany it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that they think God will cause them to die. This can be made clear. AT: "God will cause us to die because we have seen him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: We are sure to die, because we have seen God

contextId.information: This means that Samson thinks she is beautiful. "I am pleased by how beautiful she is" or "she is beautiful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means that he thought she was very beautiful.  AT: "he was pleased by how beautiful she was" or "he thought she was very beautiful" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to Samson's wife's relatives. This can be stated clearly. AT: "the young men" or "her relatives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These were from the plunder he had taken from Ashkelon. AT: "the sets of clothing that he had taken" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Samson intended to sleep with his wife. This can be stated clearly. AT: "I will go to my wife's room, so we may sleep together" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I will go to my wife's room

contextId.information: This means that he gave her to be his friend's wife. This can be stated clearly. AT: "so I gave her to be married to your friend" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: so I gave her to your friend

contextId.information: He is suggesting that Samson take her as his wife. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Take her to be your wife instead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Samson thinks that he will be innocent if he attacks the Philistines because they wronged him. This can be stated clearly. AT: "I will be innocent if I hurt the Philistines because they have wronged me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I will be innocent in regard to the Philistines when I hurt them

contextId.information: Samson's wife's father gave her in marriage to Samson's friend. This can be stated clearly. AT: "took Samson's wife and allowed her to marry Samson's friend" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: took Samson's wife and gave her to his friend

contextId.information: The Philistines are comparing how they want to kill Samson to how he killed many of the Philistines. AT: "kill him like he killed many of our people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: do to him as he has done to us

contextId.information: This refers to the cave in the cliff of Etam where Samson had gone in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:15:07|15:8]]. Here the words "up from" mean that they had brought him away from the cave. AT: "away from the cave in the large rock" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Samson was not travelling alone, he was being led by the men who had tied him with ropes. AT: "When they came" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "I will be as weak as any other man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I will be like any other man

contextId.information: Samson pulled out the fabric from the loom when he pulled his hair away from the loom. This can be stated clearly. AT: "pulled away his hair, taking with it the pin of the loom and the fabric in the loom" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: he pulled out the fabric and the pin from the loom

contextId.information: This means that he is devoted to God as a Nazirite. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:13:03|13:5]]. AT: "a Nazirite devoted to God" or "devoted to God as a Nazirite" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This means that they brought to her the silver that they had promised to give her if she helped them capture Samson. AT: "bringing the silver that they had promised to give her"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: bringing the silver in their hands

contextId.information: This means that he slept with his head on her lap. This can be stated clearly. AT: "with his head on her lap" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Since Samson was a prisoner, he would not be called directly, but rather the people were asking for the men in charge of the prison to bring him to them. AT: "Call for them to bring out Samson ... They brought Samson" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Call for Samson ... They called for Samson

contextId.information: This refers to a house used specifically for worshiping idols. This can be stated clearly. AT: "a house for worshiping idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means that he was living among the family of Judah, that is, the tribe of Judah. AT: "who was living among the tribe of Judah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that he is looking for a place to live and work. AT: "where I might live and have a job" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers specifically to land inherited where they would live. AT: "not received a land inheritance from" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

They traveled this way to protect the children. If Micah and his people attacked them the would reach the warriors first and not the children. AT: "They put the small children in front of themselves to protect them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: They put the small children in front of themselves

contextId.information: This refers to the Danites being too strong for Micah and his men to fight against. AT: "they were too strong for him and his men to fight" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: they were too strong for him

contextId.information: This means that she was unfaithful in their relationship and that she began to sleep with other men. This can be stated explicitly if necessary. AT: "began to sleep with other men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The woman did not answer because she was dead. This can be stated clearly. AT: "But she did not answer because she was dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means that he sent sent the different pieces to twelve different areas of Israel. AT: "sent each piece to a different place throughout Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: sent the pieces everywhere throughout Israel

contextId.information: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "was serving as priest before the ark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "fought against the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "The people of Benjamin began to kill some of the men of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: They began to kill some of the people

contextId.information: This refers back to the earlier assembly at Mizpah. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. AT: "none of the inhabitants of Jabesh Gilead had been present at Mizpah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: none of the inhabitants of Jabesh Gilead were there
